entry.title: Re: Is There a Way to Add Conditional Formula for Text In...
entry.content:
There is, what you need to do is the Clone() method to copy the property bag of the object and use Old/New to apply the changes

For more info on using Clone() and the below example see this sample app, it's C# but the same functions for VB:

how-to-parameters-in-crystal-reports-for-visual-studio-net

Look in the drop down box on the right and "Object Name -> Field Name"

Here's how to get the info: C# but the same for VB.

CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ReportObjects rptObjs;
//rptObjs = rptClientDoc.ReportDefController.ReportObjectController.GetReportObjectsByKind(CrReportObjectKindEnum.crReportObjectKindField);
rptObjs = rptClientDoc.ReportDefController.ReportObjectController.GetAllReportObjects();

foreach (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.ReportObject rptObj1 in rptObjs)
{
    switch (rptObj1.Kind)
    {
        case CrReportObjectKindEnum.crReportObjectKindField:
            CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.FieldObject fldObj1;
            fldObj1 = (CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.FieldObject)rptObj1;

            //CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum

            btnReportObjects.Text += "Name: " + fldObj1.Name.ToString();
            btnReportObjects.Text += "\n Kind: " + rptObj1.Kind.ToString() + "-> " + fldObj1.DataSourceName.ToString();

            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatRTFText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n RTF: = true";
            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatHTMLText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n HTML: = true";
            if (fldObj1.FieldFormat.StringFormat.TextFormat == CrystalDecisions.ReportAppServer.ReportDefModel.CrTextFormatEnum.crTextFormatStandardText)
                btnReportObjects.Text += "\n Standard Text: = true";

To use Clone() check out the API Ref Guide

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to include values from multiple models...
entry.content:
@tsuuu You are very close you have done most of the steps correctly. But I think the issue comes from adding a new dimension to an existing model.

When you add a new dimension, SAC does not know which value to use for the existing data rows. That is why it asks you to choose a default member. Since you selected “#” (unassigned), SAC has now assigned “#” to all the existing rows in your model for that new dimension.

Because of this, when you go to the story and try to filter by company code, the filter does not work as expected the data is actually stored with “#”, not with TEST or any other company code.

There is a simple way to fix this. Since your model is small and only has test data, I suggest this approach (DO NOT DO THIS IF ACTUAL DATA IS INVOLVED):

  1. Add the public Company Code dimension to your model.

  2. Delete the existing data in the model.

  3. Reload your data again.

When you load the data after adding the dimension, you can map the company code from your source data to this public dimension correctly.

This should make your input control work as expected.

entry.title: Scrapping Materials from Warehouse
entry.content:
Hi Experts,
I am seeking your advice on how to address a current business requirement related to our scrapping process.
At present, the warehouse receives a long list of valuated materials from Finance that need to be scrapped. The warehouse posts the scrapping using MIGO with movement type 551. After the MIGO posting is completed, the system generates a Transfer Requirement (TR) and subsequently a Transfer Order (TO), which allows pickers to use the RF gun for picking.
However, the warehouse’s concern is that this process does not include a release strategy, unlike what is available in the Purchase Order process. Because of this, the business is considering two alternative approaches:

Option 1: Sales Order (VA01) with a New Order Type for Scrapping

  1. Would require setting up a generic Sold-to Party and Ship-to Party specifically for scrapping.
  2. Proper G/L account and cost center assignment would be required to ensure correct financial posting.
  3. Limitation: This method does not support a release strategy, which is a key control requirement.

Option 2: Internal Purchase Order for Scrapping

  1. A Purchase Order can incorporate a Release Strategy, which addresses the control concern.
  2. However, questions arise regarding the supplier setup:
  3. Would this require creating an internal vendor?
  4. Would this effectively become a type of STO process, and how would the end-to-end flow work?
  5. Additional consideration is ensuring correct posting to the appropriate G/L accounts and cost centers.

I would appreciate your guidance or recommended approach to meet the following objectives:

  1. Ensure scrapping has an appropriate approval / release mechanism.
  2. Maintain an efficient warehouse execution process, including TR/TO creation and RF picking.
  3. Avoid unnecessary complexity or unintended financial impacts.

Any insights, best practices, or step-by-step guidance would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: Actual Cost Accounting and Moving Average Cost
entry.content:
Hello @makoto_kasuya91 ,

-Yes — SAP’s Actual Costing (Material Ledger Actual Costing) applies only to materials with Standard Price control (S).
-Materials with Moving Average Price (V) do not participate in actual costing; they are valued only at moving average, based on actual goods movements.
-When materials with mixed price controls (standard + MAP) interact (e.g., consumption, subcontracting, multi-level BOMs), SAP calculates:
*Actual cost rollup for standard-priced materials only
*MAP materials consume or issue at the current moving average, without revaluation during actual costing

Example:-

 

ItemMaterial A (FG)Material B (Component)Material C (Component)
Price ControlS (Standard)S (Standard)V (Moving Average)
Price Before Posting100 USD (Std Price)40 USD (Std Price)20 USD MAP
Consumption Qty for 1 FG—1 pc1 pc
Consumption Valuation at Posting—40 USD20 USD (MAP at that moment)
Actual Events During PeriodProduced 1 FGInvoice price difference: GR 40 → IR 45 (Variance +5)Multiple GRs at different prices → MAP auto-updated (20 → 25 → 21.67)
How SAP Treats Differences During MonthNo valuation changePrice variance collected in MLMAP automatically recalculated after each GR; no variance collected
Participation in Actual Costing (ML Period-End Closing)YesYesNo
What Happens at Actual Costing Closing?Receives rolled-up variances from componentsVariance +5 USD is rolled up to FGNo revaluation; MAP remains final MAP (21.67)
Adjustment Posted at Period-End+5 USD added to actual FG costVariance settled to FG0 USD (no settlement)
Final Actual Cost ImpactActual Cost = 105 USDVariance transferredMAP consumed but not revalued

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict multiple parkings of supplier invoices
entry.content:
Problem Background:

A customer has requested a requirement to restrict the repeated parking of goods receipt reference documents and reference document items corresponding to purchase orders that have already been parked and posted. If a purchase order has already completed goods receipt, reference document, and invoice posting, it should no longer be possible to park an invoice for this purchase order.

Solution:

Attempt to meet the requirement through custom logic using a BAdI.

Analysis Steps:

1. We have previously assisted customers with invoicing requirements, and the business enhancement points we need to use are the same. You can refer to these two blogs: Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to check if the payment terms of pre made invoices are consistent with those in supplier master data | SAP Blogs and Using Custom Logic in SAP S/4HANA Cloud to restrict invoicing of purchase orders with incomplete receipts | SAP Blogs .

First, we need to add an enhancement implementation in the application - Custom Logic of SAP S/4HANA Cloud system. According to the business scenario, select the business context Procurement: Supplier Invoice and business add-in description Check Invoice Data, and fill in the implementation description and implementation identifier.

2. After adding the enhancement implementation in Custom Logic, we need to find the CDS Views that can provide the business requirement fields. After testing, for the same PO + ITEM + goods receipt, if it has already been posted, the same goods receipt document cannot be selected again for repeated parking. Therefore, the fields I use as validation conditions here are PO and ITEM numbers. At the same time, since we need to check whether this PO and ITEM have already been posted, we need to use SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5' in I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01. However, this CDS View does not have the PO and ITEM fields, so we need to use I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01. In the sample code below, I used a custom CDS View. You can create a custom CDS View YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 in your own system based on I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01, select the corresponding fields, and make adjustments.

At the same time, as I mentioned in my previous articles, in the sample code provided by the BAdI, we can find statements that can restrict the behavior that triggers the BAdI. According to our needs, we need to add the following statement to restrict the BAdI to only trigger during invoice parking, without affecting other processes:

Park: if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Park

3. Based on the above analysis, implement the BAdI. The specific code is as follows.

loop at ITEMSWITHPOREFERENCE REFERENCE INTO DATA(Supinvoice_item).
if action = if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Hold.
    select single 
    from YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 with privileged access
    where PURCHASEORDER = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDER and PURCHASEORDERITEM = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDERITEM
    and SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5'
    into (Is_Supinvoice_status) .
    if Is_Supinvoice_status = abap_true.
      append value #( messagetype = 'E' messageid = 'MRM_BADI_CLOUD' messagenumber = '001' messagevariable1 = '暂存的发票有重复项目。' ) to messages.
    endif.
endif.
endloop.

Conclusion:

By reading this article and several previous blogs on similar scenarios, I hope you now understand how to use custom logic to apply certain restrictions when creating preliminary invoices for purchase orders.
You can find more information about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement-related issues at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

You can also read more blogs about SAP S/4HANA Cloud procurement at the following link: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sourcing and Procurement - SAP Community

If you have any suggestions or thoughts about this article, please feel free to share them in the comments section. I look forward to communicating with you. You are also welcome to follow my personal account, and I look forward to seeing you in the next blog post!

entry.title: Event Driven Integration Using SAP Integration Suite, Solace, HANA DB, and OpenAI Validation
entry.content:
1. Introduction

This prototype implements an event driven pattern using SAP Integration Suite and Solace. A JSON event is published to Solace and processed by an iFlow that applies AI based validation, routes the result, updates a HANA Cloud table, and records a structured log entry. The objective is to demonstrate event reception, AI assisted validation, routing logic, data extraction, and persistence on SAP BTP.

2. Overview

This prototype uses Solace as the event broker and SAP Integration Suite as the consumer and processing layer. A JSON event is published to a Solace topic, and SAP Integration Suite subscribes to this topic to receive each message. Once the event is received, the iFlow generates a trace identifier, captures the original JSON payload, applies an AI based validation step, and routes the message based on the validation result.

Two HANA Cloud tables support the processing. One table stores the final validated record. The second table stores the audit entry containing the original JSON, processing status, trace identifier, and error information.

Two iFlows are used in this prototype.

  • One iFlow publishes a JSON event to Solace.
  • One iFlow consumes the event, validates it, routes it, and updates the HANA tables.

The end to end processing sequence is as follows.

  • A JSON event is published to Solace
  • SAP Integration Suite receives the event from the subscribed topic
  • A trace identifier is generated and the payload is captured
  • OpenAI validates the payload
  • Valid messages update the CITIZEN_MASTER table
  • All messages are written to NIXP_LOG

3 Demo

4. Design Flow

Integration Flow design contains the following components.

4.1 CitizenCreated_Publisher
 
4.1.1 Implementation Details for Publisher iFlow
 
 
4.2 CitizenCreated_Consumer
 
 
4.2.1 Implementation Details for Consumer iFlow

4.2.1.1 GenerateTraceId Groovy

Creates a unique identifier that is stored as a property and used in all logs and database operations.

String traceId = UUID.randomUUID().toString();

 

4.2.1.2 CaptureOriginalPayload Groovy

Reads the incoming payload as a complete text string and stores it in ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD. This prevents streaming issues and ensures the original JSON is always available for validation, UPSERT, and logging.

message.setProperty("ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD", bodyAsString)

 

4.2.1.3 AIQualityCheck

Constructs the OpenAI request by embedding the citizen JSON and instructing the model to return a structured validation result with fields valid and reason.

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.json.JsonOutput

def Message processData(Message message) {
    // Read the original JSON as string
    String bodyString = ""
    try {
        bodyString = message.getBody(String)
    } catch (Exception e) {
        bodyString = ""
    }
    // explicit validation rules 
    String systemPrompt = """
You are a data quality validator for NIXP citizen registration events.
You must validate ONLY the following rules on the JSON payload:
1) citizenId must be present and a positive integer (e.g. 1, 2, 100).
2) firstName must be present, non-empty, and primarily alphabetic characters (letters, spaces, simple punctuation allowed).
3) lastName must be present, non-empty, and primarily alphabetic characters.
Other fields (for example dateOfBirth, address, extra, etc.) MAY be present or absent and MUST NOT influence validity.
You MUST NOT require any additional fields beyond citizenId, firstName, and lastName.
If the payload satisfies all three rules, set:
  valid = true
  reason = short explanation such as "All required fields are present and correctly formatted."
If any rule fails, set:
  valid = false
  reason = short explanation listing which rule(s) failed.
You must return ONLY a JSON object with exactly two keys:
  valid   (boolean)
  reason  (string)
""".stripIndent()
    // message with the actual payload
    String userContent = "Payload: " + bodyString
    // Build the OpenAI chat completion request
    def requestJson = [
        model: "gpt-4.1-mini",
        response_format: [ type: "json_object" ],
        messages: [
            [
                role   : "system",
                content: systemPrompt
            ],
            [
                role   : "user",
                content: userContent
            ]
        ]
    ]
    String jsonBody = JsonOutput.toJson(requestJson)
    message.setBody(jsonBody)
    return message
}

4.2.1.4 BuildChatGPTReqheader Add message header Authorication and Content-type.

4.2.1.5 Request Reply  HTTP = Address: https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions; Method = Post

4.2.1.6 AIQualityResultParser

Parses the JSON response from OpenAI and extracts two fields “valid” and “reason”. These values are stored in AI_VALID and AI_REASON and determine the next routing step.

4.2.1.7 Router

The router evaluates AI_VALID. If AI_VALID is true the message continues to the UPSERT path. If AI_VALID is false the message moves to the controlled error path. 

Valid path

ExtractCitizenProps reads ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD and extracts the values citizenId, firstName, and lastName.

4.2.1.8 SQLCreator

Exchange Property: Name = Query; Type = Expression; Value = UPSERT CITIZEN_MASTER ( CITIZEN_ID, FIRST_NAME, LAST_NAME, REGISTRATION_TIMESTAMP, REGISTRATION_CHANNEL, REGISTRATION_STATUS ) VALUES ( ${property.CITIZEN_ID}, '${property.FIRST_NAME}', '${property.LAST_NAME}', CURRENT_UTCTIMESTAMP, '${property.REG_CHANNEL}', '${property.REG_STATUS}' ) WITH PRIMARY KEY;

Message Body: Type = Expression; Body is ${property.Query}

4.2.1.9 Request Reply

A JDBC UPSERT updates CITIZEN_MASTER. A row with status Processed is written to NIXP_LOG.

Invalid path

4.2.1.10 RaiseAIValidationError Sets status Error and writes AI_REASON to ERROR_MESSAGE.

A row with status Error is written to NIXP_LOG using SQLCreatorLog (same settings as SQLCreator) Query is INSERT INTO NIXP_LOG ( CITIZEN_ID, RAW_JSON, STATUS, ERROR_MESSAGE, IFLOW_NAME, TRACE_ID, SOLACE_MESSAGE_ID ) VALUES ( ${property.CITIZEN_ID}, '${property.ORIGINAL_PAYLOAD}', '${property.STATUS}', '${property.ERROR_MESSAGE}', '${property.IFLOW_NAME}', '${property.TRACE_ID}', '${property.SOLACE_MESSAGE_ID}' );

4.2.1.11 Exception Subprocess will trigger in case of exception and uses log table to save the error information.

5 JBDC Matiral

6 Solace Setup

Solace credentials are created in “Manage Security Material”.

Create Queue
Messaging → Queues → Create Queue

Queue name
NIXP.CITIZEN.CREATED.Q

Add Topic Subscription to Queue
Open the queue
Topic Subscriptions → Add

Topic
nixp/citizen/created

This makes the queue receive all events published on that topic.

Create REST Delivery Point (RDP)
Messaging → Client -> REST

Add REST Delivery Points

Name: NIXP_RDP


Add REST Consumer
Inside NIXP_RDP → REST Consumers → Add

Name: NIXP_REST_CONS
Remote Host:
consumer iflow endpoint….rt.cfapps.us10-001.hana.ondemand.com
Port: 443
Method: POST
Remote Path: /http/nixp/citizen/event
TLS: Enabled

Authentication: HTTP Basic
Username: CPI client id
Password: CPI client secret

Bind Queue to RDP
NIXP_RDP → Queue Bindings → Add

Queue: NIXP.CITIZEN.CREATED.Q
Post Request Target: /http/nixp/citizen/event
Add header: Content-Type : application/json

The Solace sender adapter is configured with a subscription to the NIXP topic. All events from this topic flow directly into SAP Integration Suite.

7 OpenAI model

The validation layer uses OpenAI chat completions with model gpt 4 point 1 mini. The request contains the citizen JSON and a prompt that instructs the model to return a structured JSON response with two fields “valid” and “reason”. The response is processed by AIQualityResultParser which extracts AI_VALID and AI_REASON. These are simple boolean and string values that determine routing.

Postman Test:

{
    "model": "gpt-4.1-mini",
    "response_format": {
        "type": "json_object"
    },
    "messages": [
        {
            "role": "system",
            "content": "You are a data quality validator for citizen registration events. Given a JSON payload you must decide if it is valid for processing. Return only JSON containing keys valid and reason."
        },
        {
            "role": "user",
            "content": "Payload: {\r\n \"citizenId\": null,\r\n \"firstName\": \"12345\",\r\n \"lastName\": \"\",\r\n \"extra\": \"junk data\"\r\n}\r\n"
        }
    ]
}

Output:

{
    "id": "chatcmpl-Cdn9NmTxljW2LKBsYGyArWMUXd779",
    "object": "chat.completion",
    "created": 1763599761,
    "model": "gpt-4.1-mini-2025-04-14",
    "choices": [
        {
            "index": 0,
            "message": {
                "role": "assistant",
                "content": "{\n  \"valid\": false,\n  \"reason\": \"citizenId is null, lastName is empty, firstName contains numeric characters, extra field is not allowed\"\n}",
                "refusal": null,
                "annotations": []
            },
            "logprobs": null,
            "finish_reason": "stop"
        }
    ],
    "usage": {
        "prompt_tokens": 79,
        "completion_tokens": 36,
        "total_tokens": 115,
        "prompt_tokens_details": {
            "cached_tokens": 0,
            "audio_tokens": 0
        },
        "completion_tokens_details": {
            "reasoning_tokens": 0,
            "audio_tokens": 0,
            "accepted_prediction_tokens": 0,
            "rejected_prediction_tokens": 0
        }
    },
    "service_tier": "default",
    "system_fingerprint": "fp_4c2851f862"
}

8  Execution results

Test 1 used a valid payload to create the record:

{
  "citizenId": 123,
  "firstName": "Shahid",
  "lastName": "Syed"
}
 
Test 2 used a payload in which the citizen ID was null to check whether the OpenAI model would validate the payload.
{
  "citizenId": null,
  "firstName": "Shahid",

entry.title: 驾驭智能体（Agentic AI）时代：SAP 的AI核心策略与开发者的新角色
entry.content:
今年的 SAP TechEd 大会清晰地展示了一条技术演进路径：从传统的本地部署（on premise），到云原生架构（cloud），再到如今的 AI 驱动架构（AI-driven architecture）。我们正处在一个关键的架构转型期：AI 正从一个单纯的工具，演变为一个值得信赖的队友，能够作出可靠的自主决策。

在这个 Agentic AI 时代，技术架构正在重塑，而 SAP Joule 智能体（Joule Agents）正是实现这一变革的核心支柱。

本文将深入探讨 Joule 智能体的技术基础、企业架构定位以及未来发展前景。阅读大概需要5分钟时间。

 

智能体的核心定位与体系结构

Joule Agents​ 的目标是驱动端到端流程自动化，实现“从始至终完成工作”。它们被视为 SAP Suite-first​ 和 AI-first​ 战略的关键，旨在加速企业的转型。

在 SAP 的智能体体系中， SAP构建了清晰的三层结构，以确保用户体验的简化和后端的复杂性管理。Joule是统一的业务AI交互界面, 客户与 AI 助手(AI Assistance)互动,  AI助手则编排智能体。这些智能体协同工作，打破业务孤岛，自动化跨职能的工作流。

  1. Joule（体验层）：它是 SAP 统一的业务 AI 用户体验界面，是所有 AI 智能的单一前端。
  2. AI 助手（助手层）：这些是基于角色的 AI 队友（persona-based AI teammates），通过 Joule 访问。它们围绕实际的业务角色（如应收账款经理、招聘人员）设计，是用户以自然语言进行交互的虚拟同事。
  3. Joule 智能体（执行层）：它们是专业化的构建块（specialized building blocks），负责在后台规划、推理并执行复杂的多步骤工作流。

 

智能体的工作机制与技术基础

Joule 智能体在企业级环境中可靠运行，得益于其深度集成的架构和多项核心技术。

SAP 智能体的核心竞争力源于其深厚的业务上下文（Business Context）理解能力。借助覆盖财务、供应链、人力资源和客户体验的 SAP Business Suite，AI 能够进行跨业务范围的推理，而非局限于单一系统。这种能力建立在统一、管理和治理的数据层之上，并由 SAP 知识图谱（SAP Knowledge Graph）提供支持.

深度上下文与知识图谱赋能:  

SAP 知识图谱通过赋能智能体的推理能力来提升其效率和准确性。它整合了 SAP 50 多年的业务流程专业知识，并提供关于相关流程、数据以及其关系的深层上下文。在智能体的运行时，每一步都使用知识图谱以确保业务基础的准确性。通过将知识和数据融入智能体的工作，增强了任务结果的准确性和可靠性。

数据访问与统一语义层:  

智能体通过 SAP 业务数据云（Business Data Cloud，BDC）实现对全面且安全数据的访问，从而打破了数据孤岛。BDC 作为单一可信的数据层，确保智能体能够稳定地访问企业内的所有相关数据。通过语义对齐，智能体能够统一地处理来自 SAP 和非 SAP 的数据产品，从而保障数据的一致性和可靠性。

协作与互操作性:  

在任务执行中，AI 助手协调 Joule Agents，通过规划和执行复杂工作流来自动化业务流程。智能体利用广泛的 Joule 技能库完成复杂任务。SAP 的 Agent-to-Agent（A2A）协议实现了 AI 智能体间的安全协作，使 Joule Agents 能够与第三方智能体无缝互动。

治理与控制:

智能体运行在安全的企业级框架内。SAP 确保可解释性与透明度，使用户能理解和信任 AI 建议。对于关键行动，系统会通过 Joule 寻求人工批准，从而实现自动化与监督之间的平衡。

             

智能体的构建与开发灵活性

在智能体时代，开发者角色正从代码编写者演变为智能业务架构师，要求掌握智能工作流设计和 AI 监督能力。

SAP 通过 SAP Build​ 和 SAP Build Code​ 降低开发门槛，支持意图驱动开发（Vibe Coding），允许开发者用自然语言描述意图，由 AI 生成代码、逻辑和用户界面。

SAP 为开发者提供了构建和定制智能体的灵活途径。客户可以使用 Joule Studio​ 和 Agent Builder​ 来扩展 SAP 预建的智能体。这允许客户引入自定义字段、自定义工具和自定义推理逻辑，同时保留 SAP 提供的深层集成能力。

Agent Builder 通过自然语言和拖放界面引导开发者定义智能体的角色、分配业务流程、连接相关数据，并配备相应的技能（Skills）。 构建定制智能体 对于定制智能体，开发者可选择两种主要方式：

  • 低代码（Low-Code）：使用 Agent Builder 和 Joule Studio，通过自然语言和拖放功能实现。
  • 专业代码（Pro-Code）：为追求终极控制和灵活性的专业开发者设计，允许使用任何编程语言、任何逻辑和任何现有的智能体框架（如 LangGraph， Crew AI 等）来构建智能体。扩展后的 SAP Cloud SDK for AI​ 确保与 SAP 底层原则的深度集成。

 

未来展望：AI 驱动的企业转型

Joule Agents 策略旨在加速转型，其愿景是使 AI 助手从提供建议进化到在人类的持续控制下进行端到端自主执行。随着越来越多的预建智能体被发布，它们正在各个业务功能中带来显著的效率提升。 SAP 正通过这些智能体，驱动企业从事务性工作转向战略性工作，实现更高的效率、可靠性，并改进工作质量和设计。

在智能体时代，开发者不会消失，而是正在被超级赋能（supercharged），成为智能互联业务的架构师。

entry.title: Re: SAC - Update Dimension Values in a Planning Model Wit...
entry.content:
@Wioletta_Sokolowska-Fabisz You can do this directly in the story using Distribute Value. This lets you move the data from the old ProductID to the new ProductID without deleting or reloading anything.

Steps:

  1. Select the cell for the old ProductID (for example, “A”).

  2. Right-click and choose Distribute Value.

  3. In the panel, select the new ProductID (for example, “ABC”) as the target.

  4. Click Apply.

SAC will then:

  • Create new planning records under ProductID = “ABC”, and

  • Clear the values under the old ProductID

 Example: I want to move the bookings from "Orange no pulp" to "Orange without pulp". Then here is what I would do in the story level. 

1. Have a table that shows my product dimension.

2. Right click on the original product ID which I want to transfer, and select distribute value.

3. In the "Whete to?" section of the planning panel that appears I will use the "Add Target" button to select the target product where I want the values to be transferred. Then select "Equally" as the distribution key. And verify in the live preview of table that the source values are correctly getting transferred to target. Finally click Apply.

entry.title: Re: SAC Story: How to filter a chart on another page base...
entry.content:
Adding to Michael’s answer Linked Analysis is indeed a good approach.

I would also like to mention another option that can improve the user experience:

Use a Hyperlink with Filters to Jump to the Second Page

You can add a Hyperlink to the pie chart that:

  • Navigates directly to Page 2

  • Automatically applies the selected Material as a filter on that page

This way, when a user clicks a slice of the pie chart, they are taken straight to the monthly view with the correct Material already filtered.

Steps (shown in screenshots):

  1. Right-click the chart → More Options → Add → Hyperlink

  2. Set “Link To” as Page, and choose Page 2

  3. Enable Apply Selected Dimension as a Filter

  4. (Optional) Enable Cascading Effect if you want other filters to be respected

This provides a smooth drill-down experience between pages where the user would feel like they start at a slice of pie and then navigate to a deeper analysis for that slice of pie. 

Then in view mode: the user can use the "Jump to" option that appears when clicking on slice of pie.

That will take them to the first page with the filters applied.

entry.title: Optimising Sourcing Cycle Times: What’s Slowing Down Your Sourcing Process?
entry.content:
Let’s assume you’ve read Part 1 of this series and nodded along thinking, “Yep. We’re not moving fast enough.” But here’s the thing, it’s not about working harder to source faster.  It’s about removing the friction that slows you down at every step. 

In this second part, we’re zooming in on what causes delays in your sourcing process, and how to fix them with smarter tools, repeatable methods, and a bit of process discipline.

From Bottlenecks to Business Value

Reducing sourcing cycle time isn’t about shaving a few hours off a single approval.  It’s about rethinking the full sourcing journey from end to end, from demand capture all the way to contract creation.  And it’s about turning every step into a value driver. 

Here’s the truth: most organizations lose time not because they don’t have tools, but because those tools aren’t activated, aligned, or embedded in daily execution.  Below is a framework I use in customer workshops, I call it the Sourcing Value Flow:

Key Features that Actually Deliver Time Savings

  • Enable structured sourcing with milestone-based timelines, task ownership, and SLA tracking
  • Drives 25–40% faster approvals and increases task completion visibility
  • Modifying a Sourcing Template
  • Project Template Management
  •  

 

 

  • Guided Sourcing AI recommends templates, suppliers, and content based on past events, sourcing patterns, and category context
  • This helps reduce manual setup time and improving event quality from the start
  • Joule in Guided Sourcing
  • Guided Sourcing AI Lab
  • WalkMe in Guided sourcing

 

  • Compress pricing cycles and drive competitive tension through real-time bidding events
  • Reverse Auctions reduce negotiation time by 20–50% and often improve savings outcomes
  • eAuctions Lab
  • eAuctions Value Accelerator
  • Live eAuctions Demo

 

 

  • Simplify event creation for all user types using intuitive intake, templates, and automated workflows
  • Customers using Guided Sourcing launch 2× more events per FTE, with cycle times reduced by 30–40%.
  • Guided Sourcing Demo
  • Guided Sourcing Lab
  • Guided Sourcing Playbook

 

  • Standardize and reuse event templates, scoring criteria, questions, and documents to reduce setup time
  • Template reuse reduces event creation time by up to 70%
  • Working with Sourcing Library
  • Sourcing Library Demo
  • Loading files to Sourcing Library
  •  

 

  •  Accelerate supplier identification through AI-matched recommendations and supplier filtering tools
  • Events using Discovery receive first bids 2–3× faster, especially in indirect categories
  • Creating a Discovery Posting
  • SAP Discovery Intro
  • RFI's on SAP Business Network

Final Takeaway

Every hour saved is capacity gained. The sourcing teams that win are the ones who standardize, scale, and measure. You don’t need a moonshot to reduce your cycle time; you just need to activate and adopt what already exists.

Up next? Part 3, “How” to do it. The Activation Blueprint. We’ll cover enablement structures, process insights, SAP Joule AI, and real examples of how teams go from “go-live” to “go faster.”

entry.title: Tracing Smart Forms and Driver Programs from Output Types in SAP – Debugging Made Easy.
entry.content:
Introduction: -- 

Smart Forms are widely used in SAP to generate business outputs like Order Confirmations, Billing Documents, etc. However, identifying which Smart Form and driver program are linked to a particular output type, and how to debug them, is not always straightforward. 

This blog provides a clear and separate step-by-step guide for: -- 

  • Sales Orders (VA03) – Application V1 
  • Billing Documents (VF03) – Application V3 

We'll cover how to: -

  • Identify the driver program and Smart Form 
  • Trigger and debug the output 
  • Trace the data flow using breakpoints

Section 1: Sales Orders (VA03 – Application V1) 

Step 1: Identify Output Type Configuration 

  • Go to T-code NACE 

  • Choose Application: V1 (Sales)

  • Click on Output Types. 

  • Select output type and click "Processing Routines". 

Here You’ll see: --

  • Driver Program  
  • Form Routine 
  • Smart Form name

Then we will go to the driver program and put the debugger point.

Debug via VA03: --

  • Go to VA03, enter a valid sales order.
  • Navigate to Extras → Output → Header → Print Preview.
  • The system triggers the output program, and if you've placed breakpoints in the identified driver program, it enters debugging mode.

Section 2: Billing Documents (VF03 – Application V3)

Step 1: Identify Output Type Configuration

  • Go to T-code NACE.
  • Choose Application: V3 (Billing).

  • Click on Output Types.
  • Select output type and click "Processing Routines".

Here You’ll see: --

  • Driver Program
  • Form Routine
  • Smart Form information

Then we will go to the driver program and put the debugger point.

Trigger and Debug Output from VF03: --

  • Access VF03, input the billing document.
  • Navigate to Goto → Header → Output, select the output type and choose Repeat Output.
  • Use the Further Data option to configure the output's request for reprocessing.
  • To manually trigger debugging: --
  • Use Program RSNAST00
  • Provide relevant document and output type details
  • Execute to simulate output processing and hit breakpoints

Remember: --

Debugging Smart Forms is not just about fixing errors. it's about understanding the full flow from document to output and ensuring quality deliverables to your business users.

Conclusion: --

Understanding how to trace and debug Smart Forms and their associated driver programs is essential for any SAP ABAP developer or functional consultant involved in output management.

By following the structured steps for Sales (VA03 - V1) and Billing (VF03 - V3) provided in this blog, you can:

  • Quickly locate the output type configuration using NACE.
  • Identify the correct driver program and Smart Form.
  • Set effective breakpoints and debug output logic.
  • Use tools like RSNAST00, and SOST for monitoring and troubleshooting.
  • Ensure correct data is passed from application documents to the Smart Form output

Thank You__

entry.title: Re: Add a link to an already posted Supplier Invoice (Cre...
entry.content:
Hello @JAS3311

Good to read it is clearer now and thanks for the follow-up question.

The simple answer to that question is the apps use different technical attachment frameworks. Basically, saying that the link is stored on the MM attachment object and not the FI document. The system allows the links because the app uses the MM Invoice Business Object and this supports Files and URLs. Therefore, adding a link does not violate your audit and legal restrictions which are core to the public clouds clean-core principle.

However, you cannot add links in the FI viewer because the app only allows you to read file attachments.

I hope this clarifies your question.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Extending Standard Timesheet App Using SAPUI5 Adaptation Project in BAS – Is
entry.content:
Hello Experts @Andr @ThomasQ @SUPPORT2   ,   

We are using the standard Manage My Timesheet Fiori application in SAP S/4HANA 2023 On-Premise.
Now I have a requirement to extend this standard app using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS).

 

Requirement

I need to implement custom UI logic so that the Draft mode is automatically enabled whenever the user starts creating or editing a timesheet entry.

Currently, users must manually click the “Enable Draft” checkbox, which is often missed.

Questions

  1. Is it possible to extend the standard Timesheet app (Manage My Timesheet) using a SAPUI5 Adaptation Project for an on-premise S/4HANA system?

  2. After adapting the UI in BAS, can we deploy the variant back to the on-premise ABAP repository?

  3. Do we need to configure SAP Cloud Connector + BTP Destination for BAS to access the on-premise S/4 system?

  4. Is the controller extension the correct place to implement logic for auto-enabling Draft mode?

  5. Are there any known limitations or best practices when using an adaptation project specifically for the Timesheet application?

    My Understanding (Please Confirm)

    • Adaptation Projects are supported for S/4HANA on-premise if prerequisites (SAP_UI version, UI5 version, no scaffolding app, etc.) are fulfilled.

    • Deployment requires an ABAP package and Transport Request.

    • BAS requires system connectivity through Cloud Connector + Destination using

    • Controller extension should allow injecting custom logic to auto-enable draft mode.

      Request

      Before setting up Cloud Connector and BTP Destinations, I want to confirm whether this approach is the correct and supported way to enhance the Timesheet app, and whether anyone has implemented similar customizations.

      Any guidance, confirmation, or documentation reference would be greatly appreciated.

      Thank you!

      Arbaj Shekh

entry.title: Use Case for the Special Operation Activity in SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
Background

The Special Operation Activities and Special Operation Activity Routings have been available in SAP DM since the early releases with its origin from the legacy SAP Manufacturing Execution (ME) application.  The Special Operation (the term used in ME) was quite popular and used for many years by customers and partners alike.

The initial use case driving the Special Operation development in ME was intended for quality personnel to perform an "out of box" audit of in-process material by randomly "pulling a unit" from the manufacturing line and inspecting or reviewing it in an offline setting. 

Over time, the Special Operation routing was incorporated into the nonconformance process to serve as the offline analysis and repair stations separate from the main production line.

 

Business Context

During production, it is often necessary to divert certain SFCs from their normal routing due to quality issues, engineering changes, or operator observations. Rather than modifying the standard routing for every possible exception, SAP DM allows specific SFCs to be sent to a Special Operation Activity. This creates flexibility while maintaining process control and full visibility of the SFC’s status.

Typical scenarios include:

  • A product fails an in-process inspection and requires rework or additional testing.
  • Random audits of in-process SFCs.
  • The material requires additional verification steps before returning to the normal flow.

In SAP Digital Manufacturing (SAP DM), a Special Operation Activity/Routing provides a controlled method for removing an SFC from its standard production flow and routing it to a non-standard process such as rework, inspection, or material review. This ensures that all production, quality, and genealogy data remain traceable while allowing operators to execute specialized activities that are not part of the main routing sequence.

 

Configuration

  •  Define a Special Operation Activity type in Manage Operation Activities in SAP DM that is not tied to the main routing.  This will automatically create a Special Operation Activity Routing that is available in the Manage Routings/Recipes application.
  •  With this newly created Special Operation Activity Routing, configure additional Operation Activities as required and the corresponding return paths (dispositions) after completion.
  •  While not required, it is useful to create a dedicated POD for a given special operation activity to isolate quality or rework tasks.
  • Where appropriate for certain business processes, ensure the Operation Activity POD and related Plugins are configured to recognize the special operation activity and supports SFC selection, rework data collection, and NC closure.

Here is an example of a Special Operation Activity Routing called Preliminary Material Review or PMR.

In this example, there a four disposition options:

  1. Return to Any Previous Operation
  2. Send to another Special Operation Activity Routing
  3. Scrap
  4. Done (shown as a Tick Mark and it is the Default disposition)

 

Note:  It is good practice to add the Done step to these types of routings as a reminder that Done is the default disposition when the SFC completes that Special Operation Activity.

Comment:  It is strongly recommended to not add a production routing/recipe as a disposition.

 

Execution Flow

  1. The SFC is identified as requiring rework or special processing.
  2. An SFC can be sent to a Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that has the SOA routing assigned, or an SFC can be 'pulled' into a Special Operation Activity manually when required.
  3. The SFC’s status is updates to indicate it is on the special operation activity routing.
  4. Operators perform the necessary tasks in the Special Operation Activity POD.
  5. Upon completion, the SFC is dispositioned back to the main routing or another appropriate disposition function (such as scrap, Done, or another routing), ensuring full traceability.

As with any new configuration and business process, please thoroughly define, model and test various use cases (including corner cases) in a testing environment prior to implementing in a productive environment. 

 

Triggering the Transfer of the SFC into a Special Operation Activity

Generally, an SFC can be sent to a Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that has the Special Operation Activity routing assigned, or an SFC can be "pulled" into a Special Operation Activity (operator-initiated pull into the Special Operation Activity routing).

There are multiple ways an SFC can be directed to a Special Operation Activity:

  • Manual Operator Action: At a Work Center or Operation POD, an operator can use a custom button or action (e.g., 'Send to Rework') that sends the SFC to a disposition routing. This allows quick redirection without exiting the production context.
  • Automated Quality Integration: Integration with Nonconformance (NC) processes (tests or inspections) can automatically send an SFC to a Special Operation Activity when a NC is recorded by an operator in the POD or an NC code is raised via the APIs.
  • The SFC can be "pulled" into the Special Operation Activity by specifying the SFC value and performing the Start action.  The SFC will be moved from its current location (usually on a production routing) to the Special Operation Activity.

 

Scenario 1:  Here is an example where an SFC was sent into the Special Operation Activity by logging a nonconformance that had the Special Operation Activity Routing assigned to it as a disposition option.

Below is the SFC Report showing the progression of activities as the SFC was sent from the main routing to the Special Operation Activity and subsequently returned back to the main routing.

 

Scenario 2:  Here is an example where an SFC was "pulled" into the Special Operation Activity by entering the SFC in the SFC Field of this Operation Activity POD and selecting the Start action.

 

Triggering the Exit of the SFC out of the Special Operation Activity

When the SFC completes the Special Operation Activity, the dispositions options defined in the Special Operation Activity routing will be displayed to the user.  Here are the four options previously configured and the user can select one for the next step in the process for the SFC (including Done).  The SFC will them leave the Special Operation Activity and be placed according to the selected disposition.

 

Future Enhancements

There are future enhancements planned (subject to change) for the Special Operation Activity including providing the ability to collect and report time (activities) while the SFC is on the Special Operation Activity Routing and supporting the "Change Production" use case so that if an SFC is on the Special Operation Activity Routing and a production change is incorporated, the SFC can be placed on the updated routing accordingly.

 

Benefits

  • Allows for flexibility in how an SFC is processed offline from the primary production flow.
  • Enables controlled deviation from standard production routing.
  • Provides the ability to "pull" SFCs from the production routing without having to log a nonconformance. 
  • Supports both manual and automated rework or "random audit" flows.
  • Simplifies operator experience by providing clear visual workflows for rework or inspection.

 

Conclusion

The Special Operation Activity is a useful way to temporarily move an SFC from the main routing to an offline area for nonconformance or audit purposes while allowing a means to appropriately disposition the SFC upon completion of those offline processes.

entry.title: From SAP End User to SAP Certified - My Midlife Career Switch Journey
entry.content:
Hello Beginner Corner Community,

I’m excited to share my story as part of the SAP Digital Skills Initiative !

For years, I worked as an SAP end user in the Sourcing & Procurement area, never imagining that one day I would pursue a career in the SAP ecosystem. Midlife brought a turning point, I wanted to challenge myself, learn something new, and open doors to global opportunities.

When I discovered SAP’s Digital Skills Initiative, I saw it as the perfect chance to re-skill. The program offered free learning and certification attempt, and I decided to take the leap. It wasn’t easy, I had to balance work, family, and study time, but the structured learning paths and community support made it possible.

Today, I’m proud to say that I am SAP Certified! This achievement has already started transforming my career outlook. I now feel confident to start SAP journey.  Old said "A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step" and registered Digital Skills Initiative is great start for my SAP journey. To move far and fast, I’m actively planning my next certification to deepen my expertise.

Digital Skills Initiative not only gave me a chance to learn and earn SAP certificate, but also give me confidence, a growth mindset, and a clear career direction.

Thank you, SAP, for creating opportunities for underrepresented groups and helping us unlock new possibilities.

Big thanks to David Chaviano and his dedicated team for making this learning experience so impactful !

I am excited to collaborate, learn, and grow together while contributing to the success of the SAP ecosystem !

#SAP Digital Skills Initiative,  #SAP Digital Skills @David_Chaviano1

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services - Complex Discount Structure
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services - Complex Discount Structure  

Business Scenario Overview

As a Project Manager in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services
I want to set up a customer project with complex discount structures that separate planned costs, planned revenue, contractual agreement amounts, and multiple discount types
So that I can accurately track project profitability, manage customer expectations, and ensure proper revenue recognition accounting

The standard SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services solution does not support the following complex discount scenario:

Project Financial Structure:

  • Planned Costs: $10,000
  • Planned Revenue: $25,000
  • Contractual Agreement: $21,500
  • Discount Structure:
    • Planned Discount: $1,300
    • Additional Discount: $1,200
    • Total Discounts: $3,500 ($25,000 - $21,500)

Required Functionality - User Story 1: Complex Discount Setup

As a Project Manager : I want to configure multiple discount types at the project level
So that I can differentiate between planned discounts and negotiated discounts while maintaining accurate financial planning

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Ability to define multiple discount categories (e.g., "Planned Discount", "Negotiated Discount")
  • Each discount type should have separate tracking and reporting capabilities
  • Discounts should be configurable at project, work package, or customer level
  • System should validate that total discounts align with contractual amounts

 User Story 2: Revenue Recognition with Discount Consideration

As a Project Controller : I want Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) to consider the contractual amount ($21,500) rather than planned revenue ($25,000)
So that revenue recognition reflects actual customer commitments and discount impacts

Acceptance Criteria:

  • EBRR calculations should use contractual revenue amounts for POC-based recognition
  • System should track variance between planned revenue and contractual revenue
  • Revenue recognition should properly handle discount allocation across project phases
  • Financial reporting should clearly distinguish between planned vs. contracted amounts

entry.title: SAP RPT-1 Context Model vs. Training Classical Models: The Models Battle (Python Hands-on)
entry.content:
💥The Models Battle

Predictive modeling is becoming a built-in capability across SAP, improving how teams handle forecasting, pricing, and planning. Many SAP professionals, however, aren’t machine-learning specialists, and traditional models often demand extensive setup, tuning, and repeated training, which slows down new ideas.

SAP RPT-1 offers a simpler path. It’s a pretrained model from SAP, also available in an OSS version, that lets developers and consultants produce predictions with far less technical effort, no deep ML background required.

I've explored SAP RPT-1 hands-on, comparing it with traditional regressors using Python and a real public vehicles price dataset. 

Goal: To see (as a non Data Scientist) how SAP RPT-1 behaves in practice, what advantages and limits it shows, and when it could make sense in a predictive scenario.

Usually for real-world scenario, the right approach would be consume the SAP RPT-1 though the available and simplified API, but for studies proposal and fair comparision over othe traditional ML models, the OSS fits perfectly for it:

🤔 SAP RPT-1 vs Traditional Machine Learning - Core Differences

Before diving into the code, let’s quickly revisit how traditional ML models work:

  • Training-based models like Random Forest, LightGBM, and Linear Regression learn patterns directly from data. 
  • They require hundreds or thousands of examples to tune their internal parameters.
  • Their performance depends heavily on data quantity and quality.
  • The more relevant examples they see, the smarter they get.

On the other hand, SAP RPT-1 follows a different philosophy. It’s part of the RPT (Representational Predictive Transformer) family, pretrained on a wide variety of business and contextual data. This means:

  • You don’t "train" it in the traditional sense. Instead, it uses context embeddings to predict outcomes.
  • It can be used immediately, even with smaller datasets.
  • The OSS version allows developers to experiment directly in Python.
  • No special SAP backend required.

Outcome: Traditional ML models learn from high amount of data. SAP RPT-1 already knows how to deal with small context amount of data.

🖥 The Experiment - Setup & Dataset 

Spoiler
Don't worry on "playing puzzles" copying + pasting code below. The full version is available for download at end!

To make this comparison tangible, I built a simple yet realistic Python experiment to predict vehicle selling prices using a public dataset containing car attributes like make, model, year, transmission, and mileage.

Why vehicle pricing? Because it’s an intuitive example where both traditional machine learning and pretrained AI models can be applie, and it helps visualize how prediction quality evolves as the sample size grows.

This entire analysis runs on a local Python environment with the following stack:

import os
import gc
import warnings
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from datetime import datetime
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sap_rpt_oss import SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor
import lightgbm as lgb
  • pandas and numpy for data manipulation
  • scikit-learn for classical ML regressors (Random Forest, Linear Regression)
  • LightGBM for gradient boosting comparison
  • sap_rpt_oss — the open-source Python version of SAP’s RPT-1 model
  • matplotlib for all visualizations

SAP RPT-1 OSS can be downloaded installed following official Hugging Face: https://huggingface.co/SAP/sap-rpt-1-oss?library=sap-rpt-1-oss . Python can be installed with executable download on Windows, or via Home Brew for Mac and apt commands for Linux. Libraries dependencies can be downloaded with pip commands. Googling it may not be a road blocker.

We use a sample vehicle sales dataset. The complete file is about to 88Mb but for such experiment a restricted sample of 20k as it's more than enough to prove our the concept, still it's faster and consuming less computing resources.

FeatureDescription
yearVehicle model year
makeBrand (e.g., Toyota, Ford, BMW)
modelSpecific model name
bodyType (SUV, Sedan, etc.)
transmissionGear type
odometerVehicle mileage
color, interiorVisual attributes
sellingpriceThe target variable to predict

📊 Dataset Download: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/syedanwarafridi/vehicle-sales-data?resource=download 

The dataset is loaded and preprocessed in a few simple steps:

df = pd.read_csv("car_prices.csv").sample(n=20000, random_state=42)

# Fill missing values for categorical columns
fill_defaults = {
    'make': 'Other', 'model': 'Other', 'color': 'Other',
    'interior': 'Unknown', 'body': 'Unknown', 'transmission': 'Unknown'
}
for col, val in fill_defaults.items():
    df[col] = df[col].fillna(val)

X = df[["year", "make", "model", "body", "transmission", "odometer", "color", "interior"]]
y = df["sellingprice"]

At this point, the stage is set:

  • The data is clean.
  • The environment is ready.
  • All models, traditionals and SAP RPT-1, are ready to be tested under identical conditions.

🤖 Training the Models - Three different ones

With the dataset ready, the next step is to run each model under the same conditions: same features, same target, same train/test split and same random seed. This ensures the comparison is fair and repeatable.

We evaluate prediction performance using R² (coefficient of determination), which indicates how much of the price variation the model can explain (1.0 = perfect prediction).

Training Model #1 - Random Forest

Random Forest is often the first model used in tabular ML. It works by creating many decision trees and averaging their predictions. Before training, categorical variables need to be label-encoded into numbers, a common requirement for classical ML models:

def train_random_forest(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    le = LabelEncoder()

    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = le.fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = RandomForestRegressor(
        n_estimators=150, max_depth=20, random_state=42, n_jobs=-1
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception as e:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

 

Training Model #2 - LightGBM

LightGBM is one of the most powerful models for tabular data. Unlike Random Forest (many independent trees), LightGBM builds trees sequentially, each correcting the errors of the previous one. It supports categorical features natively, which simplifies preprocessing.

def train_lightgbm(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown").astype("category")

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = lgb.LGBMRegressor(
        n_estimators=500, learning_rate=0.05, num_leaves=31,
        subsample=0.8, colsample_bytree=0.8, random_state=42
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train, categorical_feature=cat_cols)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

Training Model #3 - Linear Regression

Not fancy and even not complex, Linear Regression provides a baseline that shows: “If the relationship between attributes and price is roughly linear, how well can a simple model perform?”

def train_linear_model(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = LabelEncoder().fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = LinearRegression()
    X_train = X_train.fillna(X_train.mean(numeric_only=True))
    X_test = X_test.fillna(X_test.mean(numeric_only=True))

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

🏁 SAP RPT-1 OSS: Context Model

This is where things get interesting. SAP RPT-1 does not rely on learning patterns from the dataset. Instead, it uses a pretrained transformer architecture to infer relationships directly through context embeddings. Lean and simple, "for non-Data Science PhD":

def train_sap_rpt1(X, y):
    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor(max_context_size=8192, bagging=8)
    model.fit(X_train, y_train)

    preds = model.predict(X_test)
    r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 2055 rows:

Live view

 

🔎 Running Experiments at Multiple Sample Sizes

This section breaks down how the iterative experiment loop works, why the SAP RPT-1 OSS model has a max-context limit, and how performance changes as we scale up the dataset. By running the same models across several sample sizes, we can see where traditional ML shines, where RPT-1 stays competitive, and how both behave as the data grows.

sample_sizes = np.linspace(50, len(X), 200, dtype=int)
results, max_r2_rpt1, max_sample_rpt1 = [], 0, 0

for n in sample_sizes:
    idx = np.random.choice(len(X), n, replace=False)
    X_sample, y_sample = X.iloc[idx], y.iloc[idx]


    # SAP RPT-1 OSS (limited sample size)
    if n <= rpt1_limit:
        rpt_res = train_sap_rpt1(X_sample, y_sample)
        fn = plot_predictions(rpt_res[2], rpt_res[0], rpt_res[1], "SAP_RPT1", n)
        video_frames["SAP_RPT1"].append(fn)
        r2_rpt1 = rpt_res[1]
        max_r2_rpt1 = max(max_r2_rpt1, r2_rpt1)
    else:
        r2_rpt1 = max_r2_rpt1
        if max_sample_rpt1 == 0:
            max_sample_rpt1 = n

    # Train and plot models
    rf_res = train_random_forest(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(rf_res[2], rf_res[0], rf_res[1], "RandomForest", n)
    video_frames["RandomForest"].append(fn)

    lgb_res = train_lightgbm(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lgb_res[2], lgb_res[0], lgb_res[1], "LightGBM", n)
    video_frames["LightGBM"].append(fn)

    lin_res = train_linear_model(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lin_res[2], lin_res[0], lin_res[1], "LinearModel", n)
    video_frames["LinearModel"].append(fn)

    results.append((n, rf_res[1], r2_rpt1, lgb_res[1], lin_res[1]))

    # Early stop if traditional model reaches SAP RPT-1
    if rf_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lgb_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lin_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1:
        break
    gc.collect()

This loop compares SAP RPT-1 OSS with traditional ML models as sample sizes increase. Each iteration randomly selects a subset of the data and trains all models on the same slice for a fair comparison. SAP RPT-1 can only run up to its max-context limit, so once the sample size exceeds that threshold, it stops retraining and simply carries forward its best R². The traditional models continue training at every step. The loop ends early when any traditional model matches or surpasses RPT-1’s best score, making the experiment efficient while showing how performance evolves as data grows.

🔚 Conclusion and Final Thoughts

 SAP RPT-1 OSS stands out because it performs well with small datasets, requires minimal code, and can generate useful predictions with just an API call and a bit of context. This makes it ideal for jump-starting predictive use cases early on, delivering fast business value without a full ML pipeline. Traditional models, however, still shine when projects mature, data grows, and fine-tuned control becomes important. It’s not about choosing one over the other, but understanding where each approach brings the most value.

 Aspect SAP RPT-1 OSS Traditional ML (RF, LGBM, Linear)
Data RequirementsLow (performs well with small samples)Medium/High (performance scales with data
Setup EffortMinimal (API call + context)Higher (preprocessing, encoding, tuning)
Training ProcessNone (pretrained context model)Full training pipeline required
Speed to InsightsVery fastModerate to slow
Best Use CaseEarly-stage predictive cases, quick baselinesMature pipelines, high control and customization
FlexibilityLimited tuning / plug-and-playHighly customizable
Business ValueImmediate, fast, accessibleStrong when optimized and scaled

This experiment highlights a simple truth: SAP RPT-1 isn’t here to replace traditional ML, it jump-starts it. With a pretrained, context-driven approach, RPT-1 delivers fast, reliable insights with very little data and almost no setup. Traditional models still excel in mature, data-rich scenarios, but RPT-1 shines as a rapid accelerator and early-value generator inside SAP landscapes.

💬Open for Exchange

If you're testing RPT-1, exploring predictive cases, or want the full code, feel free to reach out.
Happy to connect, compare experiences, and push this topic forward together.

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services - Complex Discount Structure
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services - Complex Discount Structure  

Business Scenario Overview

As a Project Manager in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services
I want to set up a customer project with complex discount structures that separate planned costs, planned revenue, contractual agreement amounts, and multiple discount types
So that I can accurately track project profitability, manage customer expectations, and ensure proper revenue recognition accounting

The standard SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Professional Services solution does not support the following complex discount scenario:

Project Financial Structure:

  • Planned Costs: $10,000
  • Planned Revenue: $25,000
  • Contractual Agreement: $21,500
  • Discount Structure:
    • Planned Discount: $1,300
    • Additional Discount: $1,200
    • Total Discounts: $3,500 ($25,000 - $21,500)

Required Functionality - User Story 1: Complex Discount Setup

As a Project Manager : I want to configure multiple discount types at the project level
So that I can differentiate between planned discounts and negotiated discounts while maintaining accurate financial planning

Acceptance Criteria:

  • Ability to define multiple discount categories (e.g., "Planned Discount", "Negotiated Discount")
  • Each discount type should have separate tracking and reporting capabilities
  • Discounts should be configurable at project, work package, or customer level
  • System should validate that total discounts align with contractual amounts

 User Story 2: Revenue Recognition with Discount Consideration

As a Project Controller : I want Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) to consider the contractual amount ($21,500) rather than planned revenue ($25,000)
So that revenue recognition reflects actual customer commitments and discount impacts

Acceptance Criteria:

  • EBRR calculations should use contractual revenue amounts for POC-based recognition
  • System should track variance between planned revenue and contractual revenue
  • Revenue recognition should properly handle discount allocation across project phases
  • Financial reporting should clearly distinguish between planned vs. contracted amounts

entry.title: Step-by-step Data Archival using SARA
entry.content:
Objective:

When migrating from ECC to S4 or with aged ECC system, we might no longer need the legacy data for day to day usage.

Wherein, the data might be needed anytime in future for crucial reasons like legal compliance, tax purposes, historical analysis, or audits.

Hence, the data needs to be archived.

 

What is data archival? How is it different from Purging?

Data archival is the process of moving inactive, infrequently used data from active storage systems to a separate, long-term storage location for retention. This frees up space and improves performance on primary systems while ensuring that important historical data remains accessible for future reference.

Purging refers to the deletion of data which is no longer required. It will not be possible to retrieve the data for later use.

 

How does it reduce costs?

There are direct and indirect cost benefits that can be obtained through data archival.

Direct Cost Savings:

  • Reduced Primary Storage Expenses
  • Lower-Cost Storage Media
  • Minimized Hardware and Maintenance Expenses

Indirect Cost Savings:

  • Improved System Performance
  • Shorter Backup Windows
  • Legacy System Decommissioning

 

Prerequisite:

Archival server/system is already configured in your system.

 

Step-by-step approach for data archival:

The following sequence of steps can be followed to archive the data.

The table ‘PAYRQ’ is opened in SE11 transaction, and the entries are viewed. Payment Request numbers start from 2 currently.

 

 

Now we need to identify the Archival Object for the corresponding Payment Request. To find it out, the transaction AOBJ is launched.

 

 

There are more than 1,500 archival objects currently. Hence, we would be needing to identify the archiving object individually. For Payment Request, SAP has provided the object FI_PAYRQ.

In the tab ‘Customizing Settings’ the following detail are pre-populated.

 

 

The logical file path needs to be maintained in Logical File Name field. In most of the cased it will be an external storage. For demonstration, we are using SAP AL11 file path.

We need to setup the variants TEST and PRODUCTIVE for delete program.

We need to setup content repository. This is the place where we store archive files.

SARA transaction is launched after identifying the archival object.

 

 

After pressing the Write button, the following screen is displayed where we have entered the variant that we are going to create now.

 

 

Select the following option and click on continue.

 

 

The following values are entered in the screen. Please note that we are going to archive the Payment Requests from 2 to 16. Then click on Attributes button to enter description  of the variant.

 

The following message will be obtained.

 

 

Clicking on back button will bring us to the previous screen. Now click on button Start Date.

 

 

We are selecting the immediate as the job needs to be triggered immediately. Then save button is clicked.

 

 

Now we’ll be able to see that start condition turned green.

 

 

Click on Spool Parameters and enter the output device as local, and click on continue.

 

Now status is all set to green and the write program can be executed.

 

 

Upon clicking execute, the following output is obtained.

 

 

Clicking on back button will take us to the previous screen.

Clicking on Statistics button will take us to the log where we will be able to see the status of current archival. It is showing in yellow as archival is done only partially, i.e., only write program has been triggered but not delete program. So the records are copied to the file path but the table entries are not deleted.

 

 

Now get back to the previous screen and click on Delete button.

 

 

Click on Customizing button and select the following option.

 

 

Setup the variants by clicking on variant button.

 

 

 

The following variants are setup.

 

 

 

Navigate to the previous screen by clicking on back button and select archive selection.

 

 

Select the session and click on continue.

Then Archive Selection has turned green.

 

 

Click on Start Date and select Immediate and save.

 

 

Now start date has turned green. Finally select spool parameters and enter local. Then click on continue.

 

 

Now all the parameters are green and we are good to execute delete program. Click on execute button and the following output is obtained.

 

 

Click on back button to navigate to the previous screen.

 

 

Clicking on Statistics will display the log where we will be able to see that the status has been changed from yellow to green.

Now we should be able to see that the entries are gone from PAYRQ table and the archive file is available in SAP AL11 folder.

 

 

 

Now the final step involves moving this to the other repository. Come back to the main screen of SARA transaction and click on Storage System.

 

 

Click on Archive files option.

 

 

Note: We need to configure content repository as in customizing settings mentioned above.

 

Now select the Archive selection button.

 

 

Select the session of archival that we want to store. Click on continue.

 

 

Now the parameter turned green.

 

 

Select start date and set it as immediate. Now both the parameters are green and we are good to execute the program to store files.

 

 

After clicking execute, the following output  will be obtained.

 

Now archiving and storage of archived files are also completed.

 

Conclusion and Takeaway:

Using the above methodology, data can be archived in SAP. The following are the takeaways:

  • SARA is the transaction or tool provided by SAP which is one of the ways to archive data. There are other archiving solutions as well.
  • Certain reports which deal with historical data will be capable of pulling the data directly from archive server.
  • Only the needed data to be archived. Its always a good practise to purge the unneeded data.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Replication Mode in Com...
entry.content:
Ni Niklas, thank you for your input. I did a bunch of testing the last few days and that are my results:

Initial Replication:

This deactivates the change pointer generation, but does not trigger any replication by itself.

You can do the initial load via app Replicate by Replication Model

Change Replication:

This does active the change pointer generation and depending on the output mode, the data gets replicated immediately or via the job.

The initial replication via Replicate by Replication Model is always possible, independently of the Replication Mode.

entry.title: Re: Is there a way to change multiple Incomplete Sales Or...
entry.content:
Good day Changhun

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references

Manage Sales Orders, Mass Change of Sales Documents, Sales Order Processing, Logistics Integration

Check out the following Blog: Incompletion Log in Sales Order - SAP SD

To summarise, due to the public clouds clean core principle, no you cannot carry out mass conversion of multiple Incomplete Sales Orders into Completed Sales Orders after fixing the issue you had. Some apps like Goods Issues and Billing do have that functionality (dedicated Apps) but this is not possible with the creation and completion of sales order because it must always pass the systems Incompletion Log.

However, since you have corrected the cause of the error that led to the issue, the clean-core offers some workarounds that will help you significantly speed up the process.

You can make use of the Mass Change of Sales Documents App.

You can create a mass-update for items visible in the app but it does not automatically complete the incompletion log. It only helps you correct common missing values before you process each order.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How does the Inventory Audit Report calculation work...
entry.content:
Hi,

B1 uses all tables that influence either stock, stock value, or both. So for example RDR1 and ORDR (Sales Order data), it does not use, but DLN1 and ODLN (Sales Delivery data), it does use. It depends entirely on which modules and functions of B1 you use. You can use the System Information functionality, from the 'View' menu, to see which tables are used in your report:

Turn it on > run the report with a single item and a year time span > open one of each type of transation that is shown in the report, using the yellow arrows, one at a time > hover (no need to click) the mouse pointer over a field and look at the bottom left corner:

The report chooses all items that have the 'Inventory item' check set, within the parameters that you have given:

The report is generated from scratch each time. It simply adds and subtracts quantities based on all trasactions related to each item. It recalculates everything transaction by transaction, as you said. This is the reason why you get the warning about it possibly running a long time. If you had a lot of items and a lot of (years of) transaction data, it would even crash in older 32 bit versions of B1.

Regards,

Johan

entry.title: 初めての Joule Skill 応用編：Automation で複数ユーザのバッジを一括リクエストしてみた
entry.content:
Joule Studio というサービスがリリースされてから約3ヶ月が経ちました。すでに SAP Tutorial にもいくつかコンテンツが公開されており、少しずつ盛り上がりを見せつつあります。一方で、「Joule Studio でどこまでできるのか？」という点は、まだ気になっている方も多いのではないでしょうか。

Tutorial の1つに 「Build Your First Joule Skill in Joule Studio」 というものがあります。以下のように、S/4 のモックからデータを参照する Action 、バッジを作成する Action を開発し、それらを利用した Joule Skill を開発する内容です。

In this tutorial, you will create an action project for accessing business partner information from an OData service representing an SAP system. You will also create an action project for creating a badge request via an OData service representing a third-party system.

 非常に勉強になる Tutorial なのですが、同僚から「例えば、複数のユーザを一気にバッジリクエストしたい場合はどうするの？」という質問をもらいました。確かに、このままの構成だと1ユーザずつ Joule にリクエストしないといけません。

それでは、複数ユーザ分をまとめてバッジリクエストできるようにしてみましょう。

ただし、ここで1つ問題があります。Joule Skill には、SBPA の Process でいうところの 「Go to Step」 や、Automation でいうところの 「forEach」 に相当するような、ループ制御の機能がありません。そのため、BusinessPartner の GET と Badge Create の POST を Joule Skill の中だけで繰り返し実行するのは難しい状況です。

そこで今回は、Automation を組み合わせる というアプローチを取ってみます。以下が完成形です。

　　

 

1. Joule Skill の仮組みを作成

Joule Skill からは Automation（および Process）を呼び出すことができます。今回は、Business Partner ID のリストを Automation に渡して処理させる構成にします。 ただし、Joule Skill 内における Automation への Input には Data Type の設定がなく、 String 型のみ です。

そのため、Joule 側では "AAAA, BBBB" のようにカンマ区切りの文字列として ID を入力してもらい、Automation 内で String から List of String に変換します。

  • Joule Skill の Input パラメータ名：BusinessPartnerList
  • Description：a list of BusinessPartner ID like "0001, 0002"

といった形で定義しておきます。

（元ネタの Tutorial では他にもいくつかパラメータを設定していますが、本記事では割愛します。）

 

2. Automation の作成

次に、Automation を作成します。一度 Joule Skill の開発画面から離れて、SAP Build Process Automation 側で Automation プロジェクトを作成します。

※ まだ Desktop Agent をセットアップしていない場合は、以下の URL を参考にセットアップしてください：
Install and Set Up Desktop Agent 3

最初に、Custom Script を使って String から List への変換を実装します。イメージは以下のような JavaScript 関数です。

function parseIds(rawIds) {
  if (typeof rawIds !== "string") {
    throw new Error("rawIds must be a string like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  const ids = rawIds
    .split(",")
    .map(s => s.trim())
    .filter(Boolean);

  if (ids.length === 0) {
    throw new Error("No valid IDs found. Expected something like 'AAA, BBBB'.");
  }

  return ids;
}

こうすることで、後続ステップで forEach を使って ID ごとの処理を実装できるようになります。

続いて、右上の Project Properties から Manage Dependencies → Add an Action Project Dependency を選択し、Tutorial で作成した Business Partner の GET と Badge Create の POST の Action Project を依存関係として追加します。

あとは、以下のようにフローを組みます。

  1. Input 文字列を String to List で List に変換
  2. forEach で ID を１件ずつ取り出す
  3. Get data from BP API の Action を呼び出す
  4. 結果を使って Create Badge の Action を呼び出す

最後に、Project Properties（右上の歯車マーク） → Attributes から、Agent セットアップ時に設定した Agent の属性を紐づけておきます。

準備ができたら、Release → Deploy を実行します。その後、Joule Skill から利用できるように、Lobby の該当バージョンで Publish to Library をクリックして公開します。

 

3. Automation の導入（Joule Skill 側）

再度 Joule Skill の画面に戻り、Run Automation を追加します。まずは、Browse All Automations から、先ほど作成した Automation を選択します。

Input パラメータ BusinessPartnerList を Automation の Input にマッピングします。

後続のステップに Send Message ノードを追加します。

これでフローが完成したら、Joule Skill 側でも Release → Deploy を実施します。

 

4. テスト

先ほども少し触れましたが、Automation には Agent が必要です（ここでいう Agent は、いわゆる AI エージェントではありません、念のため…）。

Joule Skill 内で Automation を実行する場合も、どの Agent を使うか を指定しておく必要があります。

Automation および Joule Skill をデプロイした環境に、Control Tower → Environments からアクセスします。その上で、Agent Management にて、対象の Agent を追加します。

ローカルの PC で動いている Desktop Agent の設定で、Agent Mode が Unattended になっていることを確認します。

一番右側のタブに「Joule」とあるので、作成した Joule Skill のバージョンを確認し、Launch ボタンから Joule にアクセスします。

実際にプロンプトを入力して試してみます。

それぞれの ID について Badge リクエストが登録されていることが確認できます。

やっていること自体は、Automation 側で forEach によるループを回しているだけなので、1件のリクエストにも複数件のリクエストにも対応できる構成になっています。

将来的にファイルアップロードが Joule Skill でサポートされれば、ファイルを元にさらに多くのリクエストを一括処理する、といったことも期待できそうです。

 

5. 最後に

いかがでしたでしょうか。既存の SAP Build Process Automation（SBPA）の知識をほとんどそのまま活かしながら、Joule Skill を拡張していくことができます。

一方で、

  • Go to Step のような柔軟なフロー制御が Joule Skill 側にないこと
  • Automation の Output を Joule Skill の変数に直接マッピングできないこと （Help には Output タブがあると記載されていますが、少なくとも私の環境ではまだ確認できていません）

など、現時点では少し物足りない部分があるのも事実です。 とはいえ、Joule Studio と SBPA を組み合わせることでできることは、今後さらに広がっていくはずです。これからのアップデートがとても楽しみです！

 

CoE Japan チームでは、Joule Studio だけでなく、様々な製品を対象に PoC やユースケース検証を実施しています。技術検証やアーキテクチャ検討、ベストプラクティスのご紹介などを通じて、お客様・パートナーの皆さまの SAP 活用を技術面からご支援しています。

Joule や SAP Build 周りで「こういうことはできる？」といったお悩みがあれば、ぜひ CoE Japan チームまでお気軽にご相談ください。

entry.title: Using an mqtt client with event mesh (python)
entry.content:
Hi,
I implemented a python script which connects to event mesh and subscribes to a queue.
The oauth token is retrieved successfully and the connection is established.
However every time the client tries to subscribe to a queue, the connection is closed.
This is also the case when the client tries sending a keepalive message.
This is my code:

import paho.mqtt.client as mqtt
import requests
import time

# ---------- Configuration ----------
BROKER_URL = "xxxx"      # Replace with your MQTT broker URL
BROKER_PORT = 443                     # Typically 8883 for TLS
TOPIC = "testOrgName/testEventMesh/1/test_queue"

# OAuth Configuration
OAUTH_TOKEN_URL = "xxx"  # OAuth token endpoint
CLIENT_ID = "xxx"
CLIENT_SECRET = "xxx"
SCOPE = "mqtt.subscribe"

# -----------------------------------

def get_oauth_token():
    """Fetch a new OAuth access token"""
    payload = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
    }
    response = requests.post(OAUTH_TOKEN_URL, auth=(CLIENT_ID, CLIENT_SECRET), params=payload)
    response.raise_for_status()
    token = response.json().get("access_token")
    return token

# MQTT Callbacks
def on_connect(client, userdata, flags, rc):
    if rc == 0:
        print("Connected successfully!")
        #client.subscribe(TOPIC)
        #client.publish(TOPIC, "Hello, MQTT!", qos=1)
        print(f"Subscribed to topic: {TOPIC}")
    else:
        print(f"Connection failed with code {rc}")

def on_message(client, userdata, msg):
    print(f"Received message: {msg.payload.decode()} on topic {msg.topic}")

def on_disconnect(client, userdata, rc):
    print(f"lost connection with reason {rc}")

def on_log(client, userdata, level, buf):
    print(f"{level}: {buf}")

def main():
    # Get OAuth token
    token = get_oauth_token()
    print("Obtained OAuth token")

    # Create MQTT client
    client = mqtt.Client(transport="websockets", client_id="xyz")

    # Assign callbacks
    client.on_connect = on_connect
    client.on_message = on_message
    client.on_disconnect = on_disconnect
    client.on_log = on_log

    # maybe not even necessary
    client.tls_set(ca_certs="./_.cf.eu10.hana.ondemand.com")
    client.ws_set_options(path="/protocols/mqtt311ws", headers={"Authorization": f"Bearer {token}"})

    # Connect to broker
    client.connect(BROKER_URL, BROKER_PORT)

    # Start network loop
    client.loop_start()

    try:
        while True:
            # Keep running or refresh token periodically if needed
            time.sleep(10)
    except KeyboardInterrupt:
        print("Disconnecting...")
        client.loop_stop()
        client.disconnect()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

 I have tried setting a different client id and I have verified that the topic coincides with the queue name and the queue naming rules in the service descriptor. I have also verified, that enough connections are open (there is no other connection). I also have verified, that the client is indeed connected to event mesh using the resource usage where it is, for some reason, marked as a producer.

My suspicion now is, that for some reason i have to enable the mqtt functionality or at least give some permissions for mqtt or something.

what would also be helpful would be something where i can see the logs of the mqtt broker in event mesh or at least any kind of logs.

entry.title: Re: SAP DM - Identify process instance in Monitor PPD bas...
entry.content:
Hi Ankit

in filter section there is PARAMETER filter. You can use it (unfortunatly only for 1 parameter) to search the PPD invoked by your trigger.

Ex if the trigger is on machine X and you pass X to PPD just write X in parameter filter.

Hope it works
